Award.AwardTitle: Quantification of Organic Nitrogen use in FACE and Culture Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
Much of plant nitrogen supply, particularly for trees, is supplied through symbiotic (mycorrhizal) fungi that obtain sugars from their host trees and in return transfer nitrogen. However, methodological difficulties have limited quantification of the role that mycorrhizal fungi play in meeting plant nitrogen demands. In this project, ratios of carbon and nitrogen isotopes from two field experiments at Duke University and at Rhinelander, Wisconsin will be used to assess organic nitrogen uptake by different mycorrhizal fungi and plants. This information will be combined with laboratory studies on mycorrhizal plants to provide the first realistic and quantitative estimates of organic nitrogen use. New methodologies being developed for this project will determine whether patterns of organic nitrogen use differ across ecosystems and across species of mycorrhizal fungi.

This work will develop and perfect new methods to quantify organic nitrogen use by plants and mycorrhizal fungi which will transform how researchers think about nitrogen cycling in the soil and its connections to soil carbon. This has implications for forest management. Educational work will involve collaboration with several local high school teachers to expand their use of outdoor classrooms and use of fungi as a tool to teach biology. Outreach to the public will also include educating Appalachian Mountain Club (AMC) naturalists on fungal roles in forests as well as leading AMC nature walks. The project will involve training for a Ph.D. student and several undergraduates, including recruitment of students from Elizabeth City State University, a historically black institution with strong academic ties to UNH.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nitrogen is considered the primary limiting nutrient in most forest ecosystems outside of the tropics. Thus, how nitrogen is obtained from the soil and delivered to plants is an important question in ecosystem research. Soil scientists, agronomists, and forest ecologists have primarily considered that soil microbes take up the vast majority of available nitrogen and that only inorganic nitrogen is available for plant uptake. Yet, considerable evidence suggests that organic nitrogen such as amino acids may also supply some of plant nitrogen demand. In particular, the symbiotic (ectomycorrhizal) fungi with which many plants associate could potentially obtain organic nitrogen from the soil and transfer part of it to their host plants in exchange for the energy subsidy of plant-derived sugars.

The major goals of the project were to develop techniques to show the key importance of organic nitrogen in forest nitrogen supply. We focused on using a variety of isotopic techniques to show that ectomycorrhizal fungi assimilate organic nitrogen (isotopes are elements that differ in the number of neutrons in the atomic nucleus, such as 14C (radiocarbon), 13C, 12C, 15N, and 14N). In addition, we showed that different taxa of ectomycorrhizal fungi differ functionally in their patterns of organic nitrogen acquisition. We focused on natural abundance radiocarbon measurements in archived samples, on stable isotope measurements from field experiments where 15N and 13C labels were applied, and on fungal culture studies with 15N- and 13C-labeled substrates. We also used these isotopic techniques to gain new insights into the functioning of morels that fruited after fires in Oregon and Alaska, specifically whether they were symbiotic with plants (mycorrhizal) or relied on the decay of dead organic matter for their nutrition (saprotrophic).

In a final project, the lawn fungus Amanita thiersii was used as an integrator of competition between different plant types. American lawns may provide early clues about how climate and rising carbon dioxide concentrations (CO2) will alter vegetation. Lawns are similar across much of the USA, but differ regionally in their relative proportions of the two main types of grasses, with C3 grasses like Kentucky bluegrass favored in cooler and wetter climates, C4 grasses like Bermuda grass favored in warmer and drier climates, and C3 grasses favored over C4 grasses by rising carbon dioxide concentrations. We sampled lawn mushrooms collected between 1982 and 2009 of a fungus (Amanita thiersii) that feeds on the grass-derived carbon. The carbon isotope ratios (13C:12C) of the mushrooms reflect the competition between C3 and C4 grasses as influenced by temperature, precipitation, and rising CO2concentrations. The dominant climatic influence on the different grasses was temperature, with a 1 °C increase corresponding to a 12% decrease in the proportion of C3 grasses from 1982 to 2009. But the proportion of C3 grasses increased by 18.5% over the same time frame as CO2 concentrations increased by 13.8%, from 341 to 387 parts per million. Thus, rising CO2 is already influencing plant competition on one common feature of the American landscape, the American lawn.

Currently, eight papers have been published with support from this project. The paper on the changing landscape of American lawns was featured in the “Research Spotlight” section of the American Geophysical Union (https://eos.org/research-spotlights). In addition, two post-doctoral associate, four PhD students, and 10 undergraduate students participated in the research.  Other public outreach included leading fungal forays and evening lectures through the Appalachian Mountain Club during a yearly week-long volunteer position as a naturalist in the White Mountains of New Hampshire.
